Exercise 4.5.3

Prove Proposition 4.5.4. (Hint: first prove the claim when xxx is a natural number. Then prove it when xxx is an integer. Then prove it when xxx is a rational. Then use the fact that real numbers are the limits of rational numbers to prove it for all real numbers. You may find the exponent laws (Proposition 6.7.3) to be useful.)

Proposition (4.5.4)

For any real number xxx, we have exp⁡(x)=ex\exp\p{x} = e^xexp(x)=ex.
Solution.

By definition, e1=exp⁡(1)e^1 = \exp\p{1}e1=exp(1). When n∈Nn \in \Nn∈N, we have

en=e∑i=1n1=∏i=1ne1=∏i=1nexp⁡(1)=exp⁡(∑i=1n1)=exp⁡(n).e^n = e^{\sum_{i=1}^n 1} = \prod_{i=1}^n e^1 = \prod_{i=1}^n \exp\p{1} = \exp\p{\sum_{i=1}^n 1} = \exp\p{n}.en=e∑i=1n​1=i=1∏n​e1=i=1∏n​exp(1)=exp(i=1∑n​1)=exp(n).

Here, we have used the fact that both exe^xex and exp⁡(x)\exp\p{x}exp(x) satisfy the identity f(x+y)=f(x)f(y)f\p{x + y} = f\p{x}f\p{y}f(x+y)=f(x)f(y) (and induction). Moreover, because they both satisfy f(−x)=1f(x)f\p{-x} = \frac{1}{f\p{x}}f(−x)=f(x)1​, we get

e−n=1en=1exp⁡(n)=exp⁡(−n),e^{-n} = \frac{1}{e^n} = \frac{1}{\exp\p{n}} = \exp\p{-n},e−n=en1​=exp(n)1​=exp(−n),

so this proves equality for x∈Zx \in \Zx∈Z. Next, suppose pq∈Q\frac{p}{q} \in \Qqp​∈Q. Then by f(x+y)=f(x)f(y)f\p{x + y} = f\p{x}f\p{y}f(x+y)=f(x)f(y) again,

(epq)q=ep=exp⁡(p)=(exp⁡(pq))q.\p{e^{\frac{p}{q}}}^q = e^p = \exp\p{p} = \p{\exp\p{\frac{p}{q}}}^q.(eqp​)q=ep=exp(p)=(exp(qp​))q.

Here, the second equality holds since p∈Np \in \Np∈N. Because ex>0e^x > 0ex>0 and exp⁡(x)>0\exp\p{x} > 0exp(x)>0 for any x∈Rx \in \Rx∈R, this implies that

epq=exp⁡(pq),e^{\frac{p}{q}} = \exp\p{\frac{p}{q}},eqp​=exp(qp​),

which settles the equality for x∈Qx \in \Qx∈Q. Finally, given any x∈Rx \in \Rx∈R, by density of Q\QQ, there exists a sequence (qn)n⊆Q\p{q_n}_n \subseteq \Q(qn​)n​⊆Q such that qn→xq_n \to xqn​→x. Thus, because exe^xex and exp⁡(x)\exp\p{x}exp(x) are both continuous functions and agree at rational numbers,

ex=lim⁡n→∞eqn=lim⁡n→∞exp⁡(qn)=exp⁡(x).e^x = \lim_{n\to\infty} e^{q_n} = \lim_{n\to\infty} \exp\p{q_n} = \exp\p{x}.ex=n→∞lim​eqn​=n→∞lim​exp(qn​)=exp(x).

Exercise 4.5.4

Let f ⁣:R→R\func{f}{\R}{\R}f:R→R be the function defined by setting f(x)≔exp⁡(−1x)f\p{x} \coloneqq \exp\p{-\frac{1}{x}}f(x):=exp(−x1​) when x>0x > 0x>0, and f(x)≔0f\p{x} \coloneqq 0f(x):=0 when x≤0x \leq 0x≤0. Prove that fff is infinitely differentiable, and f(k)(0)=0f^{\p{k}}\p{0} = 0f(k)(0)=0 for every integer k≥0k \geq 0k≥0, but that fff is not real analytic at 000.

Solution.

When x<0x < 0x<0, f(x)f\p{x}f(x) is identically 000, so it's automatically smooth there. For x>0x > 0x>0, f(x)f\p{x}f(x) is the composition of the two smooth functions exp⁡(x)\exp\p{x}exp(x) and −1x-\frac{1}{x}−x1​, so it is also smooth there. It remains to check what happens at x=0x = 0x=0. We will prove the following claim by induction.

P(k)=[∃ a rational function Rk(x) ∀x>0:f(k)(x)=Rk(x)e−1x and f(k)(0)=0].P\p{k} = \br{\exists \text{ a rational function } R_k\p{x}\ \forall x > 0 : f^{\p{k}}\p{x} = R_k\p{x} e^{-\frac{1}{x}} \text{ and } f^{\p{k}}\p{0} = 0}.P(k)=[∃ a rational function Rk​(x) ∀x>0:f(k)(x)=Rk​(x)e−x1​ and f(k)(0)=0].

Base case: k=0k = 0k=0

In this case, P(0)P\p{0}P(0) holds with Rk(x)=1R_k\p{x} = 1Rk​(x)=1 and from the definition of fff.

Inductive step:

Suppose P(k)P\p{k}P(k) holds for some k∈Nk \in \Nk∈N. Then Rk(x)=p(x)q(x)R_k\p{x} = \frac{p\p{x}}{q\p{x}}Rk​(x)=q(x)p(x)​ for some polynomial functions p(x),q(x)p\p{x}, q\p{x}p(x),q(x). Then

f(k+1)(x)=[p′(x)q(x)−q′(x)p(x)q(x)2−p(x)x2q(x)]e−1x.f^{\p{k+1}}\p{x} = \br{\frac{p'\p{x}q\p{x} - q'\p{x}p\p{x}}{q\p{x}^2} - \frac{p\p{x}}{x^2 q\p{x}}} e^{-\frac{1}{x}}.f(k+1)(x)=[q(x)2p′(x)q(x)−q′(x)p(x)​−x2q(x)p(x)​]e−x1​.

Since p′(x)q(x)−q′(x)p(x)p'\p{x}q\p{x} - q'\p{x}p\p{x}p′(x)q(x)−q′(x)p(x), q(x)2q\p{x}^2q(x)2, p(x)p\p{x}p(x), and x2q(x)x^2 q\p{x}x2q(x), it follows that the first part of P(k+1)P\p{k+1}P(k+1) holds with

Rk+1(x)=p′(x)q(x)−q′(x)p(x)q(x)2−p(x)x2q(x).R_{k+1}\p{x} = \frac{p'\p{x}q\p{x} - q'\p{x}p\p{x}}{q\p{x}^2} - \frac{p\p{x}}{x^2 q\p{x}}.Rk+1​(x)=q(x)2p′(x)q(x)−q′(x)p(x)​−x2q(x)p(x)​.

To complete the proof, for any k∈Nk \in \Nk∈N, Rk(x)R_k\p{x}Rk​(x) is a rational function, so there exists m∈Zm \in \Zm∈Z such that lim⁡x→0xmRk(x)\lim_{x\to0} x^m R_k\p{x}limx→0​xmRk​(x) exists. (You can factor the denominator of Rk(x)R_k\p{x}Rk​(x) into the form xmr(x)x^m r\p{x}xmr(x), where mmm is the multiplicity of the root 000 of the denominator. Then rrr is continuous and r(0)≠0r\p{0} \neq 0r(0)=0.) Moreover, by Exercise 4.5.8,

lim⁡y→∞eyym+1=∞,\lim_{y\to\infty} \frac{e^y}{y^{m+1}} = \infty,y→∞lim​ym+1ey​=∞,

so by composing limits,

lim⁡x→0+e−1xxm+1=lim⁡y→∞ym+1ey=0.\lim_{x\to0^+} \frac{e^{-\frac{1}{x}}}{x^{m+1}} = \lim_{y\to\infty} \frac{y^{m+1}}{e^y} = 0.x→0+lim​xm+1e−x1​​=y→∞lim​eyym+1​=0.

Putting everything together,

lim⁡x→0+f(k)(x)−f(k)(0)x=lim⁡x→0+xmRk(x)⋅e−1xxm+1=0,\lim_{x\to0^+} \frac{f^{\p{k}}\p{x} - f^{\p{k}}\p{0}}{x} = \lim_{x\to0^+} x^m R_k\p{x} \cdot \frac{e^{-\frac{1}{x}}}{x^{m+1}} = 0,x→0+lim​xf(k)(x)−f(k)(0)​=x→0+lim​xmRk​(x)⋅xm+1e−x1​​=0,

and because f(k)(x)=0f^{\p{k}}\p{x} = 0f(k)(x)=0 for x<0x < 0x<0, we automatically have

lim⁡x→0−f(k)(x)−f(k)(0)x=0.\lim_{x\to0^-} \frac{f^{\p{k}}\p{x} - f^{\p{k}}\p{0}}{x} = 0.x→0−lim​xf(k)(x)−f(k)(0)​=0.

Thus, f(k+1)(0)=0f^{\p{k+1}}\p{0} = 0f(k+1)(0)=0. By induction, we have shown that fff is smooth and f(k)(0)=0f^{\p{k}}\p{0} = 0f(k)(0)=0 for all k∈Nk \in \Nk∈N. Finally, if fff were real analytic at 000, then there exists r>0r > 0r>0 such that

f(x)=∑n=0∞cnxnf\p{x} = \sum_{n=0}^\infty c_n x^nf(x)=n=0∑∞​cn​xn

for x∈(−r,r)x \in \p{-r, r}x∈(−r,r). By Taylor's theorem we necessarily have cn=f(n)n!=0c_n = \frac{f^{\p{n}}}{n!} = 0cn​=n!f(n)​=0. But this would imply that

0<e−2r=f(r2)=0,0 < e^{-\frac{2}{r}} = f\p{\frac{r}{2}} = 0,0<e−r2​=f(2r​)=0,

which is impossible, so fff is not real analytic at 000.
